Name: Highrise
Description: The first vertical family domino game! Players match the dominos while creating a high-rise building. The taller the building the more points rewarded for each domino played. Wild dominoes and special spacers make the game strategic and captivating. The spinning game board allows every player to see the board from their position.

Name: Top Team
Description:
From the back of the box: "Play your cards right and keep possession of the ball.  build up the attack with your team cards and just hope that you aren't tackled.  The referee will award you a free kick if you're fouled, or even a penalty if you're quick enough.  Shoot!  You need goals to win, in this fast action football gane!  Collect your favourite players and clubs."

This is a simple card game where players lay cards from a face-down pack hoping they will form a sequence that would allow them to shoot.  If not, the opposing player could attempt to intercept.  This could lead to a successful tackle or a foul, which in turn could lead to a penalty.

It can be played with one or two packs of Top Team cards.  Each pack represents a different team from the upper reaches of the 1979 English First Division.

The game itself is pure chance.  Prominent players of the era were represented as 'artist's impressions'.
Families: Sports Teams: Aston Villa Football Club
Sports Teams: Manchester United Football Club

Name: DungeonCrawl
Description:
Currently freely available from 
http://home.epix.net/~caver/dungeoncrawl.pdf

EDIT: Archive link: http://web.archive.org/web/20070413153917/http://home.epix.net/~caver/dungeoncrawl.pdf

From the rulebook:

What you are now reading is a quick play, tongue in cheek, dungeon adventuring game. This is a
game were everybody plays equally - not where one player controls the bad guys and everybody
responds/submits to his decisions. Each player controls his own little band of misfits AND controls
the critters that another player will encounter. Each player is someone else's nemesis.
All encounter and miscellaneous event rolls are done in the open, and are a surprise for everybody
to enjoy. The whole point of this little endeavor is for everybody to have fun, so it helps
if you don't take things too seriously. These rules are not intended as an overly detailed, exhaustive
study in the complexities of subterranean armored combat. Nor will they require you
to undertake a prolonged course of study in order to properly equip and prepare your party for
eventual world domination.
"Elegance in Simplicity" is the rule, even when it comes to brawling in the dark recesses of the
dungeons. Hopefully you will find DungeonCrawl to be reasonably quick and reasonably fun.
Enjoy.
All players will begin the game with essentially equal parties. In the standard game, parties are
composed of 1 fighter, 1 archer, 1 cleric, 1 thief, and 1 mage. For more advanced games, players
may customize their party to suit their playing style. All players have roughly the same goal
– get their party out alive with as much loot as possible. In the basic game, the winner is determined
by the player with the most loot at the end. More advanced games have differing goals,
or specific objectives to be accomplished in order to claim victory.
But it all boils down to:
Kill Critters, Get Goodies; try to get out alive so you can brag about it.

Name: Feeding Frenzy
Description:
Two games in one!

FEEDING FRENZY

Eat your way to the top in this fast, fun, frenzied game!  When a card is played, your goal is to eat it using animal cards in your hand.  But you better hurry because the frenzy is on and other players are hungry too!  The one who eats the most cards becomes the feeding frenzy champion!

FOOD CHAIN

The name of the game is to finish the chain!  Using the animal cards in your hand, your goal is to knock other players out of the game by filling in their food chains - from spider (#1) to man (#10).  The last player left becomes the king of the food chain!

Name: Squeeze
Description: Players spin the Lucky Spinner and travel a carnival-themed board to win enough Prize Cards to to enter the Boardwalk and get to finish first.

Name: Box-Office
Description: Large Quiz game based on movies, uses similar mechanics as Trivial Pursuit (cards with several questions/answers on them). The board is organized in four parts: scenario, casting, direction and production. Each part has boxes of different colors that trigger questions about a particular topic (history of the cinema, actors, directors, films,…). The players can earn money answering these questions. The richest player is declared the winner at the end of the game.

Name: Rules for the Conduction of Colonial Period Skirmish Wargames in Miniature 1850 to 1900
Description:
Fast-paced, personalized combat during the heyday of colonial empires. Relive the Zulu assault at Rorke's Drift, the Charge of the 21st Lancers at Omdurman (with young Winston Churchill at your right), and many other exciting colonial battles. Games represent the critical point in one sector of a general engagement, or a clash between small parties of scouts. The colonial period  is remarkable for the variety of actions that can be reproduced.  With these rules, actions from the familiar British North-West Frontier and African wars, and from the unfamiliar French oerations in Madigascar or Russian siege of Geok Tepe can all be fought.

Each player must plot every action to be performed by the miniature figure which represents him on the playing table. Rules cover anything from Melee combat to falling off of a horse. A pair of percentile dice are required and must be purchased separately.

Name: Franken-Quartett
Description:
This card game features major cities in Franconia, a German region rich in history and (only) politically part of Bavaria. Cities include Nürnberg, Würzburg, Bayreuth, Bamberg, and Rothenburg, among others.

The object of the game is to collect melds of cities by winning cards from your opponent in classical quartet showdowns.

Franken-Quartett is a variant of a Quartett game, with a splash of Top Trumps thrown in.  Each player has 5 cards of different towns. each card has informations about population, size, founding year, et c. One active player say a category and 'most' or 'fewest', and both players simultaneously play one card.  both reveal their cards, and the player with the card in the chosen category that is the declared 'most' or 'fewest' gets both cards.  The aim is to collect four cards of one  city -- one Quartett.

The player with three Quartetts wins.

Name: 4-Way Spelldown!
Description:
From the Publisher's website:

Put your spelling skills to the test! Roll the two letter dice and use the letters on the dice and your letter keys to make a word. Flip over any keys used, the first player to flip over all 10 letter keys wins the game.

For Example: 
If you roll the letter R and the letter A.  Flip up your G key to make RAG.  If you're really sharp, flip up both your G and B key to make GRAB!  Sounds easy, right?  Roll two RED letters and make any one of your opponents flip their keys down and start over. 
 Contents:
Wooden Board Game 
Sliding cover for easy storage
2 letter dice
Instructions

Name: Da Vinci Code Sudoku
Description:
Sudoku using Ancient symbols from the Da Vinci Code.

Players take turns by calling out 1 type of symbol, they then place as many of that symbol as they can.  Be careful, if your opponent spots an incorrect tile placement on your board, you get a penalty point.

Comes with Magnetic Sudoku Board, 216 Magnetic symbol tiles and book of 50 puzzles.

Name: Burst
Description: 2 Players compete as they construct a sphere using magnetic tiles. Each player gets 10 Hexagons and 6 Pentagons.  You roll a die and can only play a piece of the color that you roll.  The goal is to get rid of all your tiles first.  But remember, 2 tiles of the same color are not allowed to touch.

Name: Clone!
Description: Players build a structure by adding magnetic polyhedral tiles.  The tiles can only be connected to the shape and color that they match.  It's okay to flip or turn the structure but if it falls apart then you lose!

Name: Lingo
Description: Card is drawn. Player puts marker on same picture on his or her individual board.  Cards continue be drawn until one player wins with five markers in a row (vertically, horizontally or diagonally).  Educational value comes from reading the word (in a language not native to the player) which corresponds with the picture.

Name: Äffchen
Description:
Many different fruit cards lie spread on the table. The object is to find certain fruits and their correct color. By asking questions one moves closer the goal.

---

Viele verschiedene Früchtekarten liegen ausgebreitet auf dem Tisch. Es gilt, bestimmte Früchte und deren richtige Farbe zu finden. Durch Fragen rückt man dem Ziel näher.

Name: Baby Animal Lotto
Description: For ages 3 1/2 to 6 years old, this game has 4 lotto cards with pictures of 9 baby animals. Players draw from 36 cards and try to match pictures.

Name: Agvato
Description:
Players attempt to get their pieces to the other side of the board first by using their cards. These cards are acquired on every turn and allow certain moves, either in direction or distance.

---

Jeder Spieler verfügt über 9 Spielfiguren einer Farbe. Der Zug eines Spielers wird durch Spielzugkarten bestimmt. Im Spiel sammelt man möglichst viele Chips ein.

Name: Bambou
Description:
This game is derived from the climbing competitions of the Bambous, who always played in teams of three in championships in old bamboo groves. The crew which was gathered at the top first won the won the golden bamboo sheet. 
Players roll dice to move upward and need to find the best strategy to make use of the irregular growth of the bamboo. When two opposing pieces are at the same height, they have to duel by dice to determine who can go up and who has to go back down.


Dieses Spiel ist abgeleitet von den Kletterwettbewerben der Bambous, die immer in Mannschaften zu dritt in alten Bambushainen durchgeführt wurden. Dabei gewann die Mannschaft das goldene Bambusblatt, die als erste im Blätterdach versammelt war.

Name: 5 Minuten Denk mal
Description:
"5 Minuten Denk mal" (maybe "5 minutes of thinking") is a traditional german paper & pencil game that might be called "categories game" in the US. This one is a special variation with 85 double sided small cards giving 170 possible categories. It can be played by 8 players or 8 teams.

In each of the 6 rounds played 6 cards where used giving 6 new categories. Also one small card will used giving the first letter for each category. Players have to find clues on each category starting with the drawn letter while the sandtimer is running for 5 minutes. There are categories like "capital city", "island", "cartoon character", "color", "or "insect". If a player could make a clue for each category he is allowed to stop the actual round and all other players have to stop writing too.

Each of the 6 rounds will be scored seperately. Players will get a higher score for each answer if they have found a unique clue (10 points), if two players have the same answer there will be only 2 points, only 1 point if there are more than 2 players with the same clue. 
Each player(or team) also can use a joker once per game that will doubled there score of that round.
 The game belongs to a series of (at least) 6 games called "Fröhliche Freizeit" - packed in small but beautiful bookcase boxes similar to the wellknown 3M card games.

Game components
85 small double sided category ards
27 letter cards
 8 joker cards
 1 5 minute sand timer
 1 scorepad
 1 rules sheet


"5 Minuten Denkmal" lehnt sich in seinem Reglement an das klassische "Stadt-Land-Fluß"-Spiel an. Es reicht jedoch in den behandelten Wissensgebieten weit über dieses hinaus.

In 5 Minuten Denkmal, dem modernen Stadt-, Land-, Fluß-Spiel ohne Grenzen, hat jeder Spieler oder jedes Spielerteam in dem 6 Runden umfassenden Spielablauf die Möglichkeit, einmal in einer Runde den Joker zu setzen und so seine Punktezahl für die betreffende Runde zu verdoppeln.

Kleines Buchkasetten Spiel aus der Serie "Fröhliche Freizeit" die aus mindestens 6 Spielen besteht.

The object of the game is to be the first to score 77 points by winning rounds by playing the highest value of cards. The deck consists of 49 cards numbered 1 through 7 in seven coloured suits. In each round each player lays a meld of matching number or matching suit from a hand of seven cards. Points are scored according to the number of cards played and the total points value of the meld. The player with the highest score wins that round and keeps all the cards played by all players. When the deck is exhausted each player adds the number of cards won from that deck to a running total, the deck is shuffled and the game continues until one player's running total reaches 77. At that point the game stops immediately with that player winning.

Es gilt, in jeder Runde eine möglichst wertvolle Kartenkombination auszuspielen, um Rundensieger zu werden.  Denn als Rundensieger gewinnt man die ausgespielten Karten.

Name: Criss Cross
Description:
Criss Cross is played on a cross-shaped board with each player setting up their five pieces in one arm. A ball is placed in the center. The object is to get the ball into an opponent's goal.

Players are moved by die roll, one at a time. If a player's piece ends up in the space with the ball and they have the majority of the pieces in the space they take another turn to move a piece with the ball.

If you succeed in carrying the ball over an opponent's goal line they give you a scoring marker. To win the game you must score six goals and they must be divided evenly among your opponents.

There are a few additional rules covering things such as interceptions.

Name: Alphabet Game
Description:
From the box: Beginning spellers are introduced to letters and word formation by sight and touch.

Players compete to finish words on cards by collecting letters from spaces as they move their pawns around the board.

Name: PlunderChess
Description: In this chess variant, the standard rules apply with the added feature that when a player makes a capture, the capturing piece acquires the ability to move like the captured piece later in the game. This power may only be used once, and then the piece reverts to normal. The game comes with a set of vests to slide over the top of pieces, to serve as a reminder of what power the piece has plundered.

Name: Zygomar
Description: Zygomar is a clown with the multiple aspects who will pose a series of varied challenges in the areas of observation, speed, anticipation, memory, mime, or even logic.

Name: Apprenti sorcier
Description: This is a board game apparently sold in book form.  Events are determined with a paragraph system reminiscent of West End's Tales of the Arabian Nights.

Name: Addition Bingo
Description: Addition Bingo is a children's educational game, made to teach children the very basics of addition.

Name: Obsession
Description:
Obsession is a unique strategic-action game, which keeps you thinking. In order to play this interactive game, you need skill, quick reaction and strategic judgment.

You have to defend your men against all the attacks by your opponents, and block their plans in order to become the first to reach the center of the 3-dimensional board. (based on box-information)

Name: Monochrom
Description: Abstract two-player game with short playing time. Connect all your pieces on the board. You can move in a straight line, but you cannot stop before you hit an obstacle. But you can bring one adjacent piece with you.

Name: Tabulos: Leer de tafels met Dokus
Description: Children's game about table manners and food. Probably published in the early '90s.

Name: Rode Ridder Avonturenspel
Description: Based on the popular comic books and novels De Rode Ridder (written by Karel Biddeloo). Each player either plays De Rode Ridder or one of his opponents. The game book contains scenarios for play. In each scenario De Rode Ridder has to fulfill a quest, and his opponents do everything they can to stop him.

Name: Leksis
Description:
Description from the back of the box:

Leksis is a literary game, where you construct your own crossword puzzles. Again and again.

You can play alone or with others, and you decide for yourself how hard it should be.

Leksis contains 240 letter-pieces. A game where you can play with word puzzles in any language.

Name: Les Cracks
Description: This French cycling game from the '80s is played on a 69*22cm. board that 2 to 5 cyclists, each controlled by a player. Before the game starts, players choose how many étappes will be played (usually between 4 and 8). At the start each player has 6 cards in his hand. A card can contain advantages or bad luck (when this card is played it is played as bad luck to another cyclist). After every turn a the hand is refilled till 6. Every étappe is 200km. The winner of the game is the player who scores the best in the overall classifying of all étappes.

Name: Maillot Jaune: Le Jeu de Bernard Hinault
Description:
This cycling game is based upon the Tour de France. The box contains 1 board (46x46 cm²), 6 cyclists, 2 dice, cyclist cards and energy indicators. The game consists of 3 different étappes or stages.

Each player controls one cyclist with 3 stars in one specialty, either climbing, descending or riding on a flat terrain. The stars (3, 2 and 1 respectively) determine how fast a cyclist can go on each type of terrain. To speed up, there are two ways to attack, either a risky or normal attack. A risky attack means that the energy of the cyclist will decrease. A cyclist can also follow the slipstream of another player, which will cost the cyclist in front 1 energy point. Winner is the player who gets the best overall result in the 3 stages.

The "Maillot Jaune, Le Jeu de Bernard Hinault" version is based upon Tour de France legend Bernard Hinault, five time winner of the Tour.

Name: Horseshoe
Description: Horseshoe or Block is the English names for a game played in southeast Asia. It is a simple game of blockade played by two players on a board of five points, with each player having two pieces. The aim of the game for a player is to block the pieces of the other so as to prevent his movement.

Name: Madelinette
Description: Madelinette is a small, simple game of blockade, probably invented by J &  J Loader for their book, Making Board, Peg and Dice Games. There seems to be no reference to this game before the publishing of this book.  Two players strive on a board of seven points, each with three pieces, to block in their opponent's pieces so that the opponent cannot move.  Information on this game is sparse, as it is overshadowed by the similar-looking three men's morris, for which it is often mistaken.  A game board in the Hull and East Riding Museum, in Yorkshire, England, is often mistaken for this game in photographs but would rather seem to be an incomplete three men's morris board, this has been confirmed by the curator.

Name: Milk Race Game
Description:
At the time that this cycling game was released the Milk Race was the only professional multiple-day cycling race in the United Kingdom. It was published by British company Jason Games.

Each player controls one cyclist on the board. The movement is determined by spinning a wheel in the middle of the board and by dice. There are also tactical cards that can be played. The board also has sprint and time trial sections.

Name: Cyclo
Description:
The first version (Lampre edition) in 1999 was made for the Italian Lampre cycling outfit and only distributed amongst their customers. The 2nd edition from 2000 was commercialized and is known as the Lotto edition. The only difference is the cover of the box.

Cyclo is a cycling game where each player controls a team of 5 cyclists, each team in a different color. The gameboard consists of 5 double strokes that can be used to form different tracks. There are 3 dice, downhill all 3 may be used, during climbing only 1 die may be rolled. Cyclists can slipstream when staying behind another cyclist.

Although this is a dice controlled game (which means luck involved) Cyclo still manages to simulate the cycling board quite well.

Name: Surf the World
Description:
Surf the World has been created by a surfer with over 40 years of surfing experience and travels. This is the perfect game to play on flat or blown-out days, or at any time with the whole family.

Wipeout! walk the nose....  Drop in on a local.

Camp at surf spots. Collect all eight wave cards from famed surf breaks. Land on a secret spot to put yourself in front.....

Take off on a wave and surf your way around the world. During your ride, you will experience the thrills and obstacles every surfer encounters.

Learn some of the history and traditions that have helped shape this lifestyle.

Surf the World is the perfect addition to the surfing paraphernalia collected by every surfer.   Once you finish the ride, you will be paddling back out for another wave.  This is a game for young and old, surfers and non-surfers.

Equipment for the trip: 
Game Board, 150 Question Cards, 48 Wave Cards, 6 Movers, 2 Dice, Rules

Name: Addition Bingo
Description: Addition Bingo is an educational children's version of Bingo, designed to teach children addition, while retaining the flavor of Bingo.

Name: UNO: New York Yankees
Description:
A series of Uno variants based on assorted major league baseball teams.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The Yankee Stadium Card. If a Draw 2 or Draw 4 card is played against you, play this card to block it. After discarding the Yankee Stadium card, designate a color of your choice and play resumes. This card can also be played at any time as a Wild card; you do not need to use it to block a Draw card. This card can also be played as your last card. The point value of the Yankee Stadium card is 50 points.

Name: Grumble, Rumble... Roar!
Description:
OBJECT:  To be the first player to move all four of his playing pieces from matching base to matching finish.

PLAY: 
1.  First player must roll a one or a four to move any of his playing pieces from BASE to START.  Play moves to the left.

2.  Once a playing piece has been placed on START, player may move four spaces, he is entitled to an additional turn.

3.  Each time a player rolls a four and is able to move four spaces, he is entitled to an additional turn.

4.  A player must roll the exact number to move his playing pieces into the HOME spaces.

5.  A player may not pass or land on one of his own playing pieces.

6.  When a player lands on a space occupied by ANOTHER PLAYER, he replaces that player's playing piece with his own and sends the other player's playing piece back to the matching base, where that player must start again.

BONUS:
1.  When a player's roll of the die places his playing piece exactly on any of the six black BONUS spaces, around the center of the board, he may, on his next turn, choose to move that playing piece around the board, using the black BONUS spaces only and thus shorten the path to HOME.

2.  He moves the number of spaces as rolled, counting around the BONUS spaces until he reaches the row by his HOME and continuing down that row the remaining number on the die.

DOUBLE BONUS:
1.  The center black space is a double bonus space that may be entered from any location on the board, by rolling the exact number to land there.

2.  In order to leave the double bonus space, a player must roll a one and he then proceeds to any of the six bonus spaces on the board.
IN BOTH OF THE ABOVE BONUS CASES, IF A PLAYER LANDS ON A BONUS SPACE ALREADY OCCUPIED BY ANOTHER PLAYER, RULE 6 OF PLAY APPLIES.

TO WIN:  To be the first player to move all four playing pieces to the matching home is the winner.

Name: Palabras Ocultas
Description:
A game in Scattergories's line, published in 1990 by Borras Plana S.A en España. The players (or teams) have to write many words that begin with the corresponding letter and of the category of the indicated letter, before the sand timer runs out. It has 24 topics and different letters. Play for 12 turns.

---

Un juego en la línea de Scattergories, publicado en 1990 por Borras Plana S.A in Spain. Los jugadores (o equipos) han de escribir la mayor cantidad de palabras que empiecen por la letra correspondiente y de la categoría de la carta indicada, en el tiempo que marca un reloj de arena. Tiene 24 temas y letras diferentes. Se juega en 12 turnos.

Name: La Etapo
Description: This huge French cycling game consists of a massive 108*73cm. vinyl mapboard, 6 teams of 3 cyclists each and 1 yellow and 1 white cyclist. Also included: 1 die and 66 cards. The game is bilingual in French and... Esperanto (!). Each team consists of a sprinter, a climber and a rouleur (time rider who is strong on flat terrain). At the start of the game every player (sporting director) also receives 4 tactical cards that can be played at any moment. There also is a point system for the individual overall classification, the mountains and a point system for the teams so a player can go for different objectives. He can try to win the teams championship, mountains or go for the individual overall win with one of his cyclists.

Name: Chasse Patate
Description: Chasse Patate is a cycling game designed by Eric Le Bras, who lives in La Rochelle, France. The dimensions of the board are 59x41cms. There are 5 teams of each 2 cyclists (plastic figures). Tactics- and bad luck card plus 4 dice make the game complete. Each team has one climber and one rouleur. Movement is done by rolling the dice but the cards also have an influence. The board is divided into different étappe sections and has an interesting mechanism to determine time differences for the overall classifying. Winner is the player whose team does best for the overall lead.

Name: Olympics 1980
Description: This game based on the Olympics has quite a large box (70x43cm.) and a big plastic board that includes an athletic track. Players have to participate in 8 events: 400mt. spring, javelin, shot put, pole vault, spear throwing, marathon high jump, and long jump. The rulebook is after a classic intro told in a comic book way. Vintage game for collectors, made in Belgium.

Name: Herstory
Description:
When you play Herstory, your travel along the game path will in many ways parallel the experiences of women throughout four hundred years of American history.

Your playing marker will be sent backward and forward on the board depending on whether an event described on your "Herstory card" was a victory or a defeat for women's advancement. You will also be sent to areas of the game board which symbolize key aspects of women's lives: home, employment, personal style, and public achievement. As American women have known both frustration and triumph in their struggle for equality, you too will progress or lose ground on the board as you learn the landmark developments of women's history, the fight for women's suffrage, and the continuing effort for fair treatment at work and at home.

The game is designed for both simple and more complex play. Those players who have had little exposure to women's history will most enjoy the simple version, which familiarizes them with details and people but does not test their knowledge. Those players who are ready for the risks (and pleasures) of a challenge will enjoy the complex version. Here questions are asked and must be answered in the course of pursuing the goal and planning game strategy.

In both game versions, the objective is to reach the end of the path where the Statue of Liberty stands as a symbol of freedom of choice and opportunity - the life goal of both women and men in America.

Name: African-American Discovery
Description:
Publisher:

African-American Discovery is a trivia board game that helps you learn and review facts about significant African-Americans, African-American history, and African-American culture.

The object of the game is to score points by discovering the other players' famous names before your name is discovered, by answering history questions from the Fact-Finder cards, and by winning points on various squares on the board.

The game is won when there is only one player left. However, in a game in which a time limit is set, the player with the highest score wins.

Name: Insider Dealing
Description:
From the rules:
"Insider Dealing is a fun boardgame which recreates all the excitement of dealing - legal and illegal! - in the Stock Exchange."

The object of the game is to make it back to the start square with £1 million. As you would expect, players hope to make profits by buying and selling shares in one or more of six companies whose prices can rise or fall dramatically during the course of the game. Share prices are affected by several means.
1 - Market Information cards. These have immediate effect on one (or more rarely all) companies once a player lands on a particular square
2 - The Stock Exchange. Players select a company in which they have a minimum holding and roll dice to determine the extent and direction of the share price of that company.
3 - Inside Information cards. The most fun, these cards can be kept by players and played at the most advantageous moment. For example, by raising a share price immediately before you sell, or dropping it as you want to buy (or your opponents sell!).

This UK game was released at the height of the yuppie, 'greed is good' period in the late 80's.

Name: Little Bo Peep
Description:
Little Bo Peep has lost her sheep and you must spin and move to find them...

Play starts with four sheep of each player's respective color on the board, plus a black sheep in the middle. Regular sheep may be picked up in passing. The black sheep may only be picked up when you have all four of your own sheep and must be landed on by exact count. The player to successfully claim his own four sheep plus the black sheep wins.

The game has no copyright date, but pre-dates the use of zip codes in U.S. addresses.

Name: LEGO Dominos
Description:
Match the Colors and Stack Away!

Build your way across the board with LEGO® Dominos – the first color-based Dominos game! Players match and stack their dominos based on color, choosing to zig zag their way to the finish line or block an opponent.

It's great fun for kids to learn colors and practice fine motor skills and fun for adults too!

Contains 56 LEGO bricks, 28 LEGO plates, game board and instructions.

Name: Scribe
Description:
Scribe is a pen and paper game for two players.  The board, a 9x9 super grid of 3x3 mini grids, is simple enough to be drawn by hand.  There are two major components of play: a mapping mechanism and a system of glyphs, or patterns of orthogonally adjacent squares.  The mapping mechanism works as follows.  Your last move points to the mini grid in which your next move must be made.  For example, if your last move was in the upper left corner of a mini grid, then your next move must be made somewhere in the upper left mini grid.  The glyph system works as follows.  There are 19 named glyphs of various sizes from 1 to 9 orthogonally adjacent squares.  Glyphs that you form during play are worth points.  The majority of points scored in a mini grid wins the mini grid.  The winner of the majority of mini grids wins the game.

For the complete rules to Scribe, see http://marksteeregames.com/

Online Play


    Super Duper Games

Name: Shape of Things
Description: A matching game in which each player blindly selects an object from a pouch and sees if it matches his game board.  Matches can either be shape only for very young children or shape and color for young children.

Name: Courtyard
Description:
From the publisher:
It is the height of the castle building era in Europe - and it is a matter of national pride that the royal couple's courtyard be the most ornate and splendid in the land.

Courtyard melds high-quality wooden components, traditional medieval themes, and simple border drawing mechanics to create a strategy game with a timeless feel.

Contains:
80 laser engraved wooden tiles
4 Player Tile Trays

Name: Duck Duck Boom
Description:
From the publisher:
The only thing more irresistible than the title is the addictive gameplay.  Watch out for Sooperduck!

Duck Duck Boom! is a fun game that offers a few twists.   Choose your target and take aim!  Add a little "helper" to improve your aim.  But beware, your opponents also add "helpers" that can help or hinder your efforts, and every once in a while, one of the ducks shoot back!

A great family game that also teaches basic addition and subtraction.

Contains:
30 ducks, 25 "Helper" tiles, 5 tiles of Boom!
2 Custom Dice
Rules

Name: Cambridge
Description:
Publisher's Description:
A challenging word game. The next step in the evolution of Hangman. A new board every time. Players write their word and begin a race to "reveal" the letters. A few twists on the same old word game. Challenging family fun.

Includes:
26 Alphabet tiles
4 "Honor" tiles
5 Player tokens

Name: YangTzee
Description:
Publisher's Description:

Collect your tiles from the Sphere.   Rain to the Stream.   Stream to the Sea.

YangTzee is the "ancient" game of tile matching that's as swift as a stream.  Each tile has two symbols and one blossom.  Match blossoms in order to score.  Simple rules, top-notch wooden components, surprising depth of play.

Contains:
45 Wooden Tiles
1 Scoring Track
4 Scoring Markers
2 Tile Trays

Name: Sand Castles
Description:
Publisher's Description:

Sand Castles is a 2-player game of flexible building strategy.   Players must compete against the waves and each other.  Whoever builds the most castles wins.     There are always two castle designs to build.   Roll the dice, collect the sand pails, towers and waves, and build your castles one "block" at a time.

Intuitive rules, a new challenge each game.

Kids love it.  Great for improving spatial and planning skills.

Contains:
60 Wooden "Builder" Tiles
24 Wooden "Castle" Tiles
2 Custom dice

Name: Extreme!
Description:
Publisher's Description:

You are an Extreme! athlete, trying your hand at a variety of Extreme! sports. But be careful.  Extreme! sports pose Extreme! risks.    Injuries can happen at any time.  Choose your sport, roll the dice, and try to have the longest, most Extreme! career!

A humorous "injury management" game about Extreme! sports.

Contains:
3 custom Extreme! Dice
4 player mats
50  Extreme! condition markers

Name: Saga
Description:
From the rules

"Each [player represents a] raider [who] sets out with 500 men and his aim is to take Perth.  Before taking Perth, he must hold at least 6 other settlements and must enter Perth with no fewer than 100 men."

Movement on a hex map and hazards on the map will cause you to lose men on your way.  You can raid other players settlements.

Name: Oscar Robertson's Pro Basketball Strategy
Description:
Part of a 5 game series of Rocky Graziano (Boxing), Vince Lombardi (Football), Gil Hodges (Baseball), Rod Gilbert (Hockey), and Oscar Robertson (Basketball).

Historical players are rated on 2 basic and 1 optional factors and advancement on court and shooting is dice and table driven.  Results in high level treatment as players fall into broader groupings.

Name: Speed Circuit: Turnier Kurs
Description:
The Speed Circuit Turnier Kurs was issued by "Das Spiel" in Hamburg and took the idea from the 1979 released edition "Speed Circuit Tournament Tracks".

The "Turnier Kurs" has also 2 tracks, a qualifying and a tournament track. Main differences to the original are a longer straight line and less curves on the qualifying track and a remarkable extension of the tournament track.

Expands:

    Speed Circuit

Name: Rod Gilbert's Violent World of Pro Hockey
Description:
Part of a 5 game series of Rocky Graziano (Boxing), Vince Lombardi (Football), Gil Hodges (Baseball), Rod Gilbert (Hockey), and Oscar Robertson (Basketball).

Historical players are given numeric offensive and defensive rating, with goalies having an alpha rating.  Puck advancement and shooting is dice and table driven.  Rules for fatigue require use of multiple lines and defensive pairs.  Results in high level treatment as players fall into very broad groupings with the linear ratings.  E.g., every forward was rated 1 on defensive.

Name: Gil Hodges' Pennant Fever
Description:
Part of a 5 game series of Rocky Graziano (Boxing), Vince Lombardi (Football), Gil Hodges (Baseball), Rod Gilbert (Hockey), and Oscar Robertson (Basketball).

Historical players are rated with batters having a numeric contact and alpha power factor.  Pitchers had a numeric pitching factor and numeric endurance factor.  Certain players had special fielding or running or power pitching factors.  Interaction of pitching and contact numbers and dice roll drives each at bat.  Results in high level treatment as players fall into broader groupings with the linear numbers (contact and pitching numbers 3-9).

Name: Rocky Graziano Presents a Century of Great Fights
Description:
Part of a 5 game series of Rocky Graziano (Boxing), Vince Lombardi (Football), Gil Hodges (Baseball), Rod Gilbert (Hockey), and Oscar Robertson (Basketball).

Historical boxers are grouped into two weight categories (light heavy/heavy and Middle to light) and rated on 8 different punch strategy categories, with 23 cards corresponding to the ratings (3 for each of first 7 strategies but only 2 clinches) plus an endurance rating.  Players play hidden cards five times per round and there is a matrix for the interaction of all 23 cards.  the die is only used on knockdowns.  Because of the much wider variety of ratings, a fairly high difference is achieved for the 50 fighters included.  Variations change some of the card interactions to eliminate possible "perfect strategy" which might be available in certain boxer combinations.

Name: The Time Tunnel Card Game
Description: Deck of cards with 4 suits of 1-13 representing 4 eras and two "time tunnel" cards and randomizing spinner directing travelers to each of the 4 eras.  Various games could be played as variations of rummy, trick taking etc.  Issued to take advantage of Time Tunnel television series which did not turn out as popular as hoped.

Name: Börse
Description:
This Heyne travel game is played on 3-piece board of 9x16 size. A exchange rate table is also included.

Players travel around the board, change the value of the shares as indicated on the landed spaces, buy and sell shares and try to have the most money at the end.

The bank starts with a limited amount of money - depending of the number of players - and the game ends, when the bank has no money left.

Name: Canyon
Description:
This Heyne travel game is played on 2-piece board of 8x8 round points. The 4 center points and 2 adjacent points are omitted; they form an impassable canyon.

Both players place their 15 tokens in one edge of the board and try to reach the other side - around the canyon. Jumping over tokens allows for faster movement of the tokens and jumping over an opponent's tokens eliminates them.

The game ends, when all (remaining) pieces of one player have reached the opposing edge. Every token scores points - the further the token gets the more points are scored.  The player with the most points wins the game.

Name: Contactic
Description:
This game in travel format is played on a 3-piece board, 9x13 in size when assembled. Each player has 60 tiles. They come in 6 different designs, having 1-4 sides in the player's color and 0-3 sides in neutral white.

Every turn, a player draws one of his tiles and places it on the board according to the placing rules. Since the players have no tiles in hand to choose from, the chance that a tile cannot be placed (and a turn is missed) is relatively high. However, the unplayable tiles come into game later.

The game ends, when either all tiles are laid out or no further placement is possible. The player with the largest contiguous "island" is the winner.

Name: Cristallo
Description:
This Heyne travel game is played on 3-piece board showing 2 identical halves with 26 round points each.

Players place 1 token per turn on the board trying to form a certain geometrical form with their pieces. When no player succeeds in reaching this, the game proceeds with movements of the token, still trying to form such a geometrical form.

But now, captures of tokens is possible by moving a token to a space, where an opposing piece is staying... but on the other half of the board! To identify the "mirrored" points, the points each have letters from A-Z.

A winning position can now also be reached when an opponent has only 3 tokens left.

Name: Falle
Description:
The Heyne travel game "Falle" (=trap) is played on a board of 16x17 size with home regions of 8x4 spaces for the 2 players.

Each player has 8 playing pieces and 6 traps of different sizes. The traps are secretly deployed in the home regions by writing their position on a piece of paper.

Object of the game is to occupy one of the 2 opposing center spaces, which are in the opponent's home base and therefore well protected by the secret traps. As soon as a opposing token steps on a space with a trap, the trap is revealed (by placing the accompanying tile on the board) and it becomes an obstacle for both players from now on.

Name: Phalanx
Description:
This Heyne travel game is played on a 2-piece board of 5x5 spaces. Each player has 5 tokens. Two opposing sides of the board are used as staring positions, but the 5 spaces always contain 2 tokens of one color and 3 tokens of the other.

Object of the game is to form a straight line of 4 tokens. To equalize the advantage of occupying the middle space of the board, this space must be left after 3 succeeding turns.

Included with this game are the rules for a second game, called "Lanxy". It is played with 3 tokens per player are uses only the inner 3x3 spaces of the board. Object of the game is to form a straight line of 3 tokens. But the player reaching this has not won the game yet: he scores a certain amount of points, depending on where he could form that row. The whole Lanxy consists of 5 games and the player with the most points is the winner.

Name: Sing-Sing
Description:
This Heyne travel game is played on a 4-piece board showing 2x3 prisons and several traveling ways between them.

Each player has 18 tokens in 3 colors. The 6 tokens per color form 3 "tribes" of tokens, where one is the master tribe.

Object of the game is to capture all 6 tokens of the opposing master tribe. This is not so easy, because captured tokens can be rescued from the prisons and brought back into the game. Another problem is, that the tokens can only enter the game by throwing a 6. A player on the way to losing the game can therefore try to inhibit tokens from his master tribe to enter the game!

Name: CraCa
Description:
CraCa is a fast paced game of chance that combines the excitement of Casino craps and the challenge of strategic card play.

The game also allows you an opportunity to learn the basic rules of real Casino crap.

CraCa has all the fun and excitement of real Casino action.  It can be played with two to eight players, singly or as partners.  It is played and enjoyed by beginners, as well as advanced players of Casino craps.

Name: All About Charlottesville: Albemarle County, VA
Description:
To complete the game, you need to collect a number of items on a list that you receive at the beginning of the game.

You first go to the bank to get money, then you go to the different locations to get the items you need to complete the list.

Name: Where On Earth
Description: Description by publisher: WHERE ON EARTH is a game which not only entertains but also adds to your knowledge about geography, history, people and culture of the world's continents and countries. Yet WHERE ON EARTH is more than a game of knowledge since strategy and chance are employed and can influence the run of play.

Name: BrainTwister
Description:
BrainTwister
A fascinating game of logic and reasoning.
Two to four players compete trying to solve sequences of colorful geometric shapes.
 A sequence-solving game.  Players are shown a series of colored geometric shapes and they try to guess the color and shape of the sixth figure of the series.  Puzzles range from the very simple to the very difficult.  Depending on a die roll, players are shown only the first three, four, or five figures of the series; they then "bet" which figure will turn up sixth (once a player bets on a shape and color, no one else can make the same guess).  In some cases, figures are shown one at a time, with players making bets after each unveiling.  Challenging, educational, and fun.

Name: Imperial Guard
Description:
Imperial Guard is published with ziplock rules. They offer fast playing for Napoleonic era battles with 15 mm or 25 mm Airfix (or similar) miniatures.

A quick reference combat table speeds up the game play. A 20-digit percentile die is required, but must be purchased separately.

From the introduction:

"The Napoleonic wargame! It conjures up images of fire-belching artillery. massed infantry columns, daring cavalry charges, all with a special color and pageantry unmatched in other historical periods.

These are rules for miniature wargamers who prefer Napoleonic combat in that grand style. There is little skirmishing here except for those seemingly isolated incidents that link into the long chain of battle."

Name: Maneuver
Description:
Maneuver is a basic game for two players intended to help those who are new to simulations to understand the fundamental rules and procedures commonly found in wargames.  It is an abstract treatment of conflict, and is not designed to cover any particular war or battle in a realistic fashion.

Components:

    8x11" map with chart
    20 die cut counters


Published in Moves magazine Issue #71, Aug-Sept 1992.

Name: TacTix
Description:
Impartial game played with the 4x4 board full of one kind of pieces. A player may remove one or more adjacent pieces from a row or column. The loser is the person who takes the last piece off the board.

Note that the person who makes the last move loses. Making the last move to lose is misere version for most games, but the "normal" goal for this game.

A number of "folk art" versions of the game with a wooden board and marbles were found on the web. Computer program versions are also available.

The 4x4 game has been completely solved and it is a second player win.

				
				
					History:The game was evidently invented by Piet Hein (also known for game Hex) in the late 1940's. It isn't clear if the game was originally conceived on an NxN board or a 4x4 board.  The game is in the public domain.

The first major publicity for the game was probably in Martin Gardner's Scientific American column in the February 1958 issue. The column and reader's responses were later re-printed in his first book collection of columns, "Hexaflexagons and other Mathematical Diversions; The First Scientific American Book of Mathematical Puzzles and Diversions." Mr. Gardner notes that reader's analysis left no doubt that the 4x4 game was a second player win even though no simply strategy was found.

Name: Blondie Goes to Leisureland
Description: This 1940 game was given to children whose parents bought an appliance from Westinghouse. Players spin and move the around a fold-out paper board featuring comic strip characters Blondie and Dagwood, purchasing appliances such as a sandwich grill and a water heater before finally reaching Leisureland (a home full of electric appliances).

Name: Scam: The Game of International Dope Smuggling
Description: This cultural novelty from Berkeley, California, features a large balloon-letter 'SCAM' logo on the poster tube that contains the rolled-up map and game components. Players roll dice and move on a colorful board, getting Connections cards or Paranoia cards, as they travel through places such as New York, Mexico, Afghanistan, South America, and even the planet Uranus, making dope deals. As they get more experience, they gain connection cards giving them more control over the way their deals go down. Surprisingly skillful undergournd adult drug themed commerce game.

Name: The Bicentennial Game
Description:
The Bicentennial Game
1776-1976
"Experience the Birth of Our Nation"

This game was published in 1976 by Doc Roc Enterprises.  This game appears to be a teaching aid, as there is little to no strategy, and focuses on highlighting the people, places, and facts of the American Revolutionary War.

It is a roll-and-move game, with a board divided into three sections: a left circular track, a right snake-like track, and a middle track that is a straight-away to the victory space on top.  Each space on the board has a bit of trivia that I assume is intended to be read aloud when a player lands on it.

The flow of the game is as follows:

Section I, People
Players roll and move on the right side of the board, landing on spaces that describe the major players of the war.  Some spaces require you to draw a card, which could move you forward or backward.   The object is to get to the end of the Section I path.

Section II, The Original 13 Colonies
Once they reach the end of Section I, players roll and move on the left side of the board, landing on spaces that represent the 13 colonies.  If a player lands on a colony that they have not previously landed, they mark on a piece of paper that they have "collected" this colony.  Players will continue on the circular path until they have "collected" all 13 colonies, which will allow them to move to Section III.

Section III, The American Character
A player rolls and moves up the center path towards the top of the board.  The player must roll exactly to land on the last space, The Bell Tower, in order to win.

Name: Zulu
Description:
The booklet contains rules designed for use with 15mm or 25 mm figures. It enables players to recreate the Boer War, actions in Northwest India, as well as battles in the Sudan of 1884.

Zulus, Fuzzie Wuzzies, Dervishes, Trained Camel Troops, Artillery, Gatling Guns as well as Hidden Movement, Zareba fortifications, Supply and Firepower are included. A painting guideline for the figures is also included.

A 20-sided percentile die is required, but must be purchased separately.

Name: Krull Card Game
Description:
Card game based on the movie.

An adding game, where the players add cards (which represent characters from the movie) to a common pile.  If the pile hits exactly 32, you capture all of the good (red) cards.  If the pile total exceeds  32, you capture the black (bad) cards.  Glaive cards allow removing cards from the pile.

Name: Los ovnis atacan
Description:
You must stop the ovnis and save the Earth by being the first player to arrive at the M marker with your pawn.

One of the Feber Juegos Cassette format games.

Name: L'Autoroute
Description:
This game was designed by the same author as Milles Bornes (1954), Edmond Dujardin. It was meant to make people more familiar with the driving code. The game won a prize: the 'Medaille d'argent au concours Lepine Paris 1949'.

The game was an ever-present on the French market under the same name since then, undergoing several editional faceliftings design-wise. The 1949 edition contained 6 small cars in lead, each car for a player. The goal of the game is to take your car to a wedding, to pick up family members and get a present on the way to the wedding. But first U have to get your driving license. This is done by moving on the track on the board and learning/respecting the road code (speed limit, unique direction). Several things can happen on the board: an accident, blown tire,... There also is a garage, a gangster, a dépanneur (troubleshooter) and a gangster that can be met on the board. Vintage game for collectors.

Name: Theodore Tugboat Cargo Game
Description:
Based on the CBC network children's television show.

From Back Cover
"Welcome to The Big Harbor, where Theodore The Tugboat and his friends spend their busy days. Young players more their tugboats from port to port, hoping to be the first to collect 4 different colored chips. Watch out where you land though; just when you think you've won, you lose a ship and have to start again."

The game has two forms of play, one without cards (younger children) and one with chance cards (older children).
To play the game you move your tugboat around the board based on a dice roll. Depending on where you land you either collect a colored disk (cargo), lose a colored disk (cargo), or nothing happens. The winner is the first player to get one of each colored disk and make it back to the beginning for the board.
In the older child version you can also receive chance cards, depending on where you land. The cards allow the player to move to specific locations, move extra spaces, take extra turns, or lose turns.

Rules in English and French.

Name: CityProGame Düsseldorf
Description:
Using the detailed street map of Düsseldorf, which is set out in four colors, each player is given five companies to be established in the city as close to the center as possible.

Once a company is established on the map, the corresponding four ‘places worth seeing’ are revealed, so familiarizing players with the sights of the city.

Contents: 80 cards, 8 counters, 3 dice, rules and city information.

Name: Gone Bananas
Description:
"In GONE BANANAS your ID, EGO, and SUPEREGO come together on a game board that confronts you with real-life situations.  You take risks and develop strategies.  You will experience 'the thrill of victory and the agony of defeat.'  But win or lose, you will know that you have been in a game!"

This is a fairly typical "special interest" roll-and-move game with a psychoanalytical theme and a couple unique twists.

As players move around the outer track, they collect ID, EGO, and WOW!/OW! (Superego) cards through square instructions and a Chance card mechanism.  You use these cards throughout the game to buy BUTTONS and ZAPPERS, and to avoid penalties.

Linked at the corners of the outer track are four independent alternate routes, one each for the themes IS/EGO/SE and GONE BANANAS.  While on these alternate paths you have the chance to earn a BUTTON (literally) of the corresponding color...but each path also entails risk and expense.

Some of the squares along the outer track where "Chance" cards are had can be "owned" by players by buying ZAPPERS with ID cards.  Once bought, the squares are marked with one of the player's ZAPPER tokens.  That player gets benefits for landing on the ZAPPER, while his opponents landing there have to give him a BUTTON or WOW! cards, and the opponent gets all his OW!s.  Each ZAPPER location can be bought and re-bought (at a higher price) throughout the game.

The game ends immediately when one player has buttons of all four colors (representing a balanced personality) and more WOW!s than OW!s (representing positive self-worth...I guess).

The production value is first-class, as is the professional artwork on the nicely-mounted board.  The bits are plastic and specially designed for the game - the player tokens are bananas on a little colored base.  The cards are the only weak spot, small print on heavily-colored, cheapish  card stock.

The double goal and constant shift of buttons might make this game a cut above the standard RaM fare.  Keeping resource cards and buttons hidden would also increase the fun...and the chaos.  I've had many of these low-volume specialty games pass through my thrifting hands, and this may be the first I actually try.  The Freudian theme might wear thin early, but who knows, I might learn something about myself...or my mother.

Name: Jungle Jaws
Description:
Jungle Jaws is a simple children's game that involves catapulting your insects into the jaws of the waiting Venus Flytraps The winner is the person who gets the most bugs into the jaws of the jungle plants!

This is a great looking game with a 2 level board - four colorful Venus Flytraps on stalks and 4 sets of 4 plastic insects in different colors. You also get 4 leaf themed catapults to launch your insects. The board is held together with 1 large elastic band and the jaws of the Flytraps also snap closed thanks to elastic bands too.

The nice thing is that each bug is different instead of 4 identical ones and that the game looks great when assembled.

Name: Bob's Bouwplaats
Description: The game consists of a 80*80cm. carpet. It is based upon the Bob the Builder character from the cartoon series. The game is dice controlled and aimed at a target group from 3 years old.

Name: Superstars
Description:
Superstars is based upon a famous TV show on the BBC in the '70s till early '80s. Topsporters from several sports camped in different disciplines to determine the best overall sportsman (the late Swedish F1 driver Ronnie Peterson includes the winners list).

In this game those disciplines are: gymnastics, cycling, soccer, table tennis, 100m. sprint, steeplechase, swimming, shooting, weightlifting and canoing.

All disciplines are played with the use of dice. The board is 49x49cm. In each discipline points can be won, the winner of the overall classifying is the superstar. Vintage game for collectors and sports lovers.

Name: BrainCheck Two
Description:
BrainCheck Two is an alignment and configuration game. It is a variation of the various Morris games. It uses a board similar to Twelve Men’s Morris, but the board is color coded so that the red lines cannot be used to create a line of three. The game only uses ten men on a side.

The game starts with a placement phase, then a movement phase. Forming a line of three in either allows a player to remove on of his opponent’s men. A player reduced to two men loses. There are a number of other rules about movement and removal of men.

Name: InQUIZitive
Description:
From the box:

The action and fun begin with the first roll of the die as you accept the exciting challenge to become the first to graduate from InQUIZitive University.

Clues Make It Different!  Strategy Makes It Fun!

At last, a quiz game in which every member of the family can compete on an equal level.  Clues are the key, eliminating the frustration of almost knowing an answer -- giving less knowledgeable or younger players a fair opportunity to think out a correct response.  So every player has a chance to win!

Name: Elemental Chess
Description:
Do you like to play chess and enjoy fantasy card games like Magic the Gathering? Then you will probably like Elemental Chess. It is based on classic chess rules but includes a twist of fantasy.

Instead of a full complement of chess pieces, each player begins the game with five pawns, two rooks, two knights, and an elementalist.

The elementalist moves like a king and is capable of casting spells from a deck of 32 cards. The spells are used to summon creatures from the various elements: earth, air, water, or fire.

Each turn a player will move an existing chess piece or cast a spell. The object of the game is to put your opponent's elementalist in checkmate.

Name: Really Wild Bug Eating Party
Description: A series of challenges are used to decide who will ultimately have to suffer the fate of eating a handful of bugs. At the start of the game players are split in to two teams and a leader for each team is nominated. Next a series of ‘bug’ cards are dealt out to each of the players. Lastly a spinner is spun to select a bug and if you’re the unfortunate person holding the most cards with that bug then you’ll have to eat it, that is unless your team can complete a challenge card…

Name: Keep the Customer
Description:
An industry-training boardgame to teach healthcare professionals and para-staff the finer points of customer service excellence from the customer's point of view so they are prepared for those tricky situations before they are faced with them in reality. Uses roll-a-die-move-around-the-board mechanics and a set of scenarios taken from real-life to role-play and discuss.

Components: 65 cards, board, game pieces, and a Healthcare Edition Facilitators Guide.
 Also comes in a Call Center edition.

Name: The Story Game
Description:
This addictive game draws out the life stories - the funny, the embarrassing, the touching, the profound - things you've always wanted to share and maybe a few things you didn't. You're sure to learn something new about the other players whether you've known them for 20 minutes or 20 years!

Wannabe storytellers of the world, unite - you have nothing to lose but your boredom!

www.thestorygame.com

Name: Cup-Game
Description: Each player becomes both manager and trainer of one of the most important soccer teams in Europe. Players must show their financial abilities buying the best defenders, midfielders and strikers available in the market, as well as making good deals when they sell other players to keep the club’s treasury in good shape. When teams meet each other in the field, the most skillful trainer will likely choose the best winning tactics and lead his/her team to the victory and eventually to the Cup’s Final match...

Name: Len Choa
Description: Len Choa is one of a number of "Leopard Games", abstract hunt games played on a triangular board.  This is the simplest of them, from Thailand, with one tiger facing six leopards on a board of ten points.  First observed by westerners in 1836 but probably older.

Name: I Believe in Santa Claus!
Description: A game of lost and found in which players help Santa collect all eight of his reindeer so he can begin his trip to visit children all over the world
